issues.text: Whether the scope of the High Court's revisional jurisdiction under section 15(5) of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 is the same as under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure or wider?

anchor.surface_text: 15.  5  The High Court may, at any time, on the application of any aggrieved party or on its own motion, call for and examine the records relating to any order passed or proceedings taken under this Act for the purpose of satisfying itself as to the legality or propriety of such order or proceedings and may pass such order in relation thereto as it may deem fit. It is manifest that the scope of sub-s.  5  of s. 15 of the Act is not the same as the scope of s. 115, Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: Whether clause (iii) of section 13(3)(a) of the Act applies where the building work required by the local authority is minor in nature, such as filling a doorway in a pillar, and can be carried out without the tenant vacating the premises?
Whether the District Judge erred in taking into consideration facts that came into existence after the filing of the eviction application under section 13 of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: the learned District Judge wrongly took into consideration facts which had come into existence after the filing of the application under s. 13 of the Act. Here again we think that having regard to the scheme and purpose of the legislation it was open to the learned District Judge to take into consideration such facts as existed at the time when the order for vacation was to come into effect.

issues.text: Whether the landlord's claim for eviction under section 13(3)(a)(iii) of the Act was bona fide?

anchor.surface_text: the Controller shall, if he is satisfied that the claim of the landlord is bona fide, make an order directing the tenant to put the landlord in possession of the building on such date as may be specified by the Controller.

holdings.text: The scope of sub-section (5) of section 15 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 is not the same as the scope of section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and is wider, not confined to questions of jurisdiction only.

anchor.surface_text: 15.  5  The High Court may, at any time, on the application of any aggrieved party or on its own motion, call for and examine the records relating to any order passed or proceedings taken under this Act for the purpose of satisfying itself as to the legality or propriety of such order or proceedings and may pass such order in relation thereto as it may deem fit. It is manifest that the scope of sub-s.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual comparison of s.15(5) empowering High Court to examine legality or propriety of orders vs. s.115 CPC limited to jurisdictional errors.

holdings.text: Clause (iii) of section 13(3)(a) of the Act is attracted only when the building work required is so extensive and fundamental that it cannot be carried out without the tenant vacating the premises; minor repairs like filling a doorway do not qualify.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of 'requires' in s.13(3)(a)(iii) read with legislative scheme protects tenancy unless vacation essential for repairs mandated by local authority.

holdings.text: The appellate court may take into consideration facts that existed at the time when the order for vacation was to come into effect, even if arising after filing of the eviction application.

anchor.surface_text: the learned District Judge wrongly took into consideration facts which had come into existence after the filing of the application under s. 13 of the Act. Here again we think that having regard to the scheme and purpose of the legislation it was open to the learned District Judge to take into consideration such facts as existed at the time when the order for vacation was to come into effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of rent legislation and s.13 allowing specified vacation date permits consideration of subsequent facts relevant to need at enforcement time.

holdings.text: The landlord's claim under section 13(3)(a)(iii) is not bona fide as the required repairs were minor, could be carried out without vacating the premises, and had already been satisfactorily completed by the tenant before the vacation date.

anchor.surface_text: one of these findings was that the landlord did number require the building to carry out the repair work which was suggested by the Municipal Committee. The Municipal Committee had suggested a very simple work of repair, namely, filling up of the doorway in the pillar so that the pillar might be one solid wall to support the screen. It has number been seriously disputed before us that such repairs companyld be easily carried out with. out the necessity of asking the respondent to vacate the building.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of cl.(iii) interpretation to facts: Municipal notices required simple masonry filling doable without vacation; pillar repaired by June 8, 1957 before Sept 25, 1957 vacation date.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether the landlord manipulated the municipal notices under sections 113 and 114 of the Punjab Municipal Act as clause (iii) of section 13(3)(a) is not attracted regardless.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney General has companytended that the learned District judge was in error in holding that the appellant had manipulated the numberices under s. 113 and 114 of the Punjab Municipal Act. We think it unnecessary to go into that question because the relevant provision in s. 13 3  a  of the Act makes it quite clear that the landlord is entit- led to an order from the Controller directing the tenant to put the landlord in possession of the building only when the landlord requires it to carry out any building work etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue moot given primary holding on scope of cl.(iii); decision avoids unnecessary fact-finding.

anchor.surface_text: the learned District Judge wrongly took into consideration facts which had come into existence after the filing of the application under s. 13 of the Act.
